author: diddledani
body: In https://github.com/diddledan/powershell-snap I have worked with @TravisEz13 to scaffold a working Snap package build based on Snapcraft and Docker build processes. Can you review and take ownership or propose alternative way of proceeding.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: We are doing an internal review.  This will take some time.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: @diddledan Do you want to go ahead and transfer ownership to the PowerShell org?

comments.author: diddledani
comments.body: Yes, I can transfer now if everything is ready...

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: Everything is ready.  Request transfer and mention that you have and I'll have someone take ownership.

comments.author: diddledani
comments.body: Seems I can't request a transfer to the PowerShell organisation on GitHub without "create repository" permission granted to my account (https://help.github.com/articles/transferring-a-repository-owned-by-your-personal-account/). I suggest instead that, either I transfer to a member of the organisation's personal account (you, @TravisEz13?) who does have create repository permission and they re-transfer it from their personal account into the PowerShell org; or, someone with create repository permission can use GitHub's "Import Repository" (https://github.com/new/import) to copy my repo, not fork, into the PowerShell org.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
The import (https://github.com/new/import) seems like the easiest way
@SteveL-MSFT  can you import this repository into the PowerShell org.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: @TravisEz13 what is this blocked on? Are you using this to track the Snap package now, or is this considered done because we have our repo now?

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: This is done.  I need to do an RFC for preview snaps

title: Take ownership of my Snap package build repository
